title: John invited 10 people to his birthday party, but each of those guests told 4 friends, who in turn asked 2 other friends to come. What percent of the party guests were the original 10 people? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is no way to determine that with the information presented. Inviting people doesn’t mean they will actually show up, and the question doesn’t state that any of them or any friends who were told about the party showed up. There is also no indication if any of these ‘friends’ were shared between the original 10 invited people and given social circles it’s likely many of these friends were not unique and were told about the party by different invitees or their friends. Furthermore, simply telling someone about a party is not the same as an invitation. Unless of course the ‘friends’ are an irresponsible student who can’t do their own homework and a rumor was spread that there were no parents at the party. In that case you can assume the answer approaches 0, as John’s home is overrun by uninvited guests. So the real question is… How many kegs will John need to buy and how much will he need to charge at the door as a cover charge to pay for the kegs and the cleanup/repairs after the party. Show your work. (Work should not consist of: ‘I asked a random stranger on the internet and they said….)

Assuming all guest/people are unique and they’re not asking the same person it would be 10/130 x 100% = 7.69% (round down) 10 people asking 4 quest each = 40 quest. each quest asking another 2 each = 80 additional quest. total people going to the party = 10+40+80 = 130 Since John is a host, he’s not a guest and thus not included.
